bioghist.p: The Academy of Natural Sciences Library and Archives were established at the founding meeting of the Academy in 1812 to support the Academy's work. The Academy Library is named in honor of Ewell Sale Stewart (1924-1987), a longtime friend and benefactor. The Library is used by the staff of the Academy of Natural Sciences, Academy members, scientists, historians, artists, graduate students, corporations, and members of the public with advanced interests in the natural world.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Library of the Academy of Natural Sciences. Materials include: library correspondence (1925-1931); catalogues of the Library's holdings, 1837; accession books. 1944-1968; acquisitions lists 1967-1995; mid-20th century registers of publication exchanges; minutes of the Library Committee, 1937-1974; correspondence with and invoices from book dealers; documents related to planning, moving the collection to the new stack building, and other library projects; materials related to Library's involvement in projects with the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) and The Associated Natural Science Institutions (TANSI); correspondence and notes related to the guide to manuscript holdings created by Venia Phillips; correspondence related to the publication of the guide to microfilms; administrative records, including procedures, budgets, time sheets, departmental activity reports, interlibrary loans, records of gifts, personnel files, records of a 1966 binding survey; and reprints. This collection includes papers from Carol Spawn, Janet Evans, Earle Spamer, Sylva S. Baker, Karen Stevens, and William J. Fox. The collection also includes materials related to Harold Shalit's survey of ornithology records in the archives.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia: Collections 591, 434, 726 (History, Correspondence, Policies), plus a number of other processed collections listed in the Manuscript and Archives Guide.
